news.title: Rocket Lab wins another defense-related space contract
news.summary: The $816 million contract follows a separate $515 million — both awarded by the U.S. Space Development Agency.

news.title: Building venture-backable companies in heavily regulated spaces
news.summary: This week on Build Mode, Startup Battlefield editor Isabelle Johannessen spoke to two founders who are working to make progress in industries ripe for disruption, despite the regulatory headaches that might have deterred many other people.

news.title: Former Patagonia CEO Rose Marcario resigns from Rivian’s board
news.summary: Marcario joined the board in 2021, and will maintain her position as chair overseeing the Rivian Foundation, which made its first grants last year.

news.title: Where are investors placing their bets next year? AI, AI, AI.
news.summary: Investors at TechCrunch Disrupt explained their focus on artificial intelligence and offered advice to founders on how to stand out in a crowded AI field.

news.title: Cursor continues acquisition spree with Graphite deal
news.summary: Graphite is an AI code review assistant that was last valued at $290 million.

news.title: Google is part of Movies Anywhere again
news.summary: Google is once again part of Movies Anywhere, meaning that movies you've purchased from Google Play and YouTube will now show up as part of your Movies Anywhere collection. news.title: Did a publisher’s slip-up reveal smaller Switch 2 cartridges?
news.summary: On Friday, retro and arcade game publisher ININ Games surprisingly announced it's been able to "recalculate production" on offering a physical version of R-Type Dimensions III for the Switch 2 because "Two days ago Nintendo announced two new smaller cartridge sizes for Nintendo Switch 2." news.title: Gemini isn’t replacing Google Assistant on Android just yet
news.summary: Google isn't quite ready to replace Assistant with Gemini on Android devices. The company said on Friday that it will "continue our work to upgrade Assistant users to Gemini on mobile devices into 2026," instead of its original plans to make the switch by the end of 2025. news.title: Next-generation nuclear reactors could get a boost from the National Defense Authorization Act
news.summary: President Trump signed the National Defense Authorization Act (NDAA) for Fiscal Year 2026 Thursday with measures that further the bipartisan push for next-generation nuclear power plants. news.title: Google lobs lawsuit at search result scraping firm SerpApi
news.summary: Google says the lawsuit is its last resort.

news.title: The evolution of expendability: Why some ants traded armor for numbers
news.summary: Ants with lots of workers tend to put less energy into making them armored.

news.summary: Inin suggests new low-cost options allowed it to "recalculate production" for full cartridge.

news.summary: LG says it'll let people delete the Copilot icon. But TV chatbots aren't going away.

news.summary: BIOS checks will only affect a limited subset of Valorant players for now.

news.title: Here’s What’s in the DOJ’s Epstein File Release—and What’s Missing
news.summary: From photos of former president Bill Clinton to images of strange scrapbooks, the Justice Department’s release is curious but far from revelatory.

news.summary: In this episode, we look back at 2025 and look ahead to what's happening in 2026—including what’s in store for Uncanny Valley.

news.title: The DOJ’s Jeffrey Epstein Files Are Here
news.summary: Forced by an act of Congress, the Justice Department has released “hundreds of thousands” of pages of documents related to Epstein—but not everything, as is required by law.

news.title: Scammers in China Are Using AI-Generated Images to Get Refunds
news.summary: From dead crabs to shredded bed sheets, fraudsters are using fake photos and videos to get their money back from ecommerce sites.
